citation.journal: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society
citation.title: UBV(RI)C JHK observations of Hipparcos-selected nearby stars

wikipedia.title: Innes' star
wikipedia.summary: Innes' star (Gliese 422) is an M3.5-type red dwarf, located in constellation Carina.

wikipedia.title: Barnard's Star
wikipedia.summary: Barnard's Star is a very low-mass red dwarf star about six light-years away from Earth in the constellation of Ophiuchus.

wikipedia.title: LP 816-60
wikipedia.summary: LP 816-60 is a red dwarf star of spectral type M4, located in constellation at 18.6 light-years from Earth.

wikipedia.title: HD 24496
wikipedia.summary: HD 24496 is a 7th magnitude G-type wide binary star and M-type located approximately 67 light years away in the constellation Taurus.

wikipedia.title: HD 32450
wikipedia.summary: HD 32450, also known as Gliese 185 is a binary star in the constellation Lepus. It is located about 28 light years from the Solar System.

wikipedia.title: GJ 1005
wikipedia.summary: The system was observed with the Hubble Space Telescope in the 1990s with its Fine Guidance Sensor.

wikipedia.title: Gliese 167
wikipedia.summary: Gliese 167 is a star in the constellation Dorado. It has an apparent magnitude of 7.634.

wikipedia.title: Gliese 710
wikipedia.summary: Gliese 710 is a star in the constellation Serpens Cauda which is expected to pass through our Solar System's Oort cloud 1.35 million years from now.

news.title: HD 189733b: Astronomers Measure Wind Velocities on Hot Jupiter Exoplanet
news.summary: Using observations from the High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS), a high-precision spectrograph on ESO’s 3.6-m telescope at La Silla Observatory, astronomers have managed to measure wind velocities on opposite sides of an exoplanet…

news.title: Wolf 1061c: Potentially Habitable Super-Earth Spotted 14 Light-Years Away
news.summary: A team of astronomers has spotted three exoplanets orbiting around the same star – Wolf 1061 – one of which is in the habitable zone.

news.title: Arecibo Observatory’s Radio Telescope Detects Strange Signals from Nearby Star Ross 128 | Astronomy | Sci-News.com
news.summary: Astronomers using the 305-m (1,000-foot) radio telescope at the Arecibo Observatory, Puerto Rico, recently detected ‘strange’ signals coming from Ross 128, a red dwarf star in the constellation of Virgo, just 10.96 light-years from Earth.
